comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: Presumably replaced by the monstrosity that is now the Department of Social Protection's offices that deal with those who are sadly homeless?

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content: "A number of firemen had an anxious moment" - I bet they did!

comment.author: 30687643@N00
comment._content: g.co/maps/snzxy yes it was replaced by quite an ugly building which is probably listed now!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/apl-irl] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mogey] Yep! That would be Oisín House.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/39393844@N04] I bet you're right! And from page 5 of that Friday's Irish Times: "... At an early stage gardai ordered the evacuation of some 40 T.C.D. students from their rooms in the building nearest the fire. Part of the roof of Dublin University Press—sited at the rear of McKenzies—was damaged by heat and water. Stocks of paper were destroyed."
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I had forgotten about that one, there were a few fires in central Dublin around that time including Dockrells in George's Street.  One of the reasons for the rapid spread was the store of paints and other combustibles.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Oh yes, the Dockrell's one was huge too, wasn't it? I think a lot of people lost their jobs in that one.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: My parents recall that there was another hardware shop located at the Pearse Street / Westland Row junction, on the corner of the Trinity campus where the Science Gallery now stands. This also burnt down to the ground in the 1970's?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/apl-irl] Crikey! What on earth was going on with hardware shops in 1970s Dublin, even allowing for higher than average proportion of combustible materials?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content: Nice one Carol, l never knew about this and I walked along Pearse Street to and from work and never realised what was the story behind the Hoarding that was erected.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: "luckily situated just opposite Tara Street Fire Station." Doesn't seem to have done them much good :-(

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/shanekillen] I was using luckily very loosely. Awful destruction, but if they hadn't been opposite the fire station then damage to other neighbouring buildings and Trinity College, etc. might have been a lot worse...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
